title.narrative: 2. Mine Action and Cluster Munitions Programme 2016 -2020

description.narrative: HALO’s work will offer four immediate benefits: physical protection, providing employment for the rural poor, assistance for victims of mine/ERW accidents, and improving rural livelihoods. Physical protection will be provided through three main activities: mine clearance, Mine Risk Education (MRE) and Weapons and Ammunition Disposal (WAD). These activities will be conducted by staff recruited from mine-impacted areas, who will be employed on a long-term basis to create security for their own communities, as specified in SRoL Sub-Goal 1.3.

The project represents a significant investment in lives and livelihoods in rural communities neglected by many NGOs due to lack of funding and poor security, where all indicators for human security are poor, economic opportunities are few, and the government is unable to guarantee security. The project will also contribute to human security in a wider sense through increasing social stability and cohesion in the target communities. Migration from Afghanistan’s rural areas, driven by unemployment and instability, can be reduced by addressing these two issues through large-scale mine clearance and WAD work. The project will offer livelihoods opportunities: the majority of land cleared will be used for grazing, foraging, or crop cultivation, representing a vital source of income for members of rural mine-impacted communities. Of the total funding requested, HALO will provide funding to a local partner organisation, Accessibility Organisation for Afghan Disabled (AOAD), in a project which will deliver critical assistance to victims of mine and ERW accidents in the target communities, who are often excluded from political, economic, and social opportunities due to their disabilities.

This project will provide immediate protection from the threat of mines and ERW for 30,532 vulnerable Afghans living in five provinces of Afghanistan, directly contributing to human security in 24 mine-impacted rural communities (Dutch Government Security and Rule of Law (SRoL)Policy Sub-Goal 1.1). The project will clear 441.5 hectares of land, destroy 30 tonnes of explosive ammunition, and provide support to 144 mine/ERW accident victims. It will contribute to wider stability and human security in the surrounding areas and therefore to the stability of Afghanistan as a whole.

Khost province is located in the south east of the country bordering Pakistan. Many refugees from Pakistan travel across the border and settle in Gulan refugee camp or within the host communities. Refugees and returnees entering Khost from Pakistan have little knowledge of the history of the land and contamination. MRE provides vital life-safing information in an area with heavy displacement and movement.

activity-description.narrative: MRE is taking place in Gurbuz district. Khost province was intended to also include mine clearance, however due to another donor being assigned these tasks, only MRE is taking place in Khost.

description.narrative: Parwan is a mountainous province North of Kabul. Much of the land is used for grazing and pastures. The nomadic Kuchi tribe regularly pass through and around Parwan province with high numbers of livestock grazing on the land.

activity-description.narrative: MRE is taking place in Parwan province. In light of displacement numbers and nomadic tribes, these populations are vulnerable without knowledge of the land and the risks of mines.

description.narrative: Laghman province is located in the east of Afghanistan. Mihtarlam district in Laghman is primarily flat area where residential buildings, gardens, yards, cemetries and roads are found. Clearance here may be more time consuming around residential buildings. Laghman province was not in the original proposal, has been added due to a reduced number of tasks in Khost, another donor was allocated tasks in Khost due to insecurities in Paktya

activity-description.narrative: Mine clearance & Mine Risk Education are taking place in this province. Clearance will hope to clear an entire distrcit by the end of the project.

description.narrative: Samangan province is located north of the Hindu Kush mountains in the Northern region of Afghanistan. Agriculture and small scale mining are the primary livelihoods. The main crops grown are wheat, barley and potato and flax. Demining will take place in the hilly and mountainous areas of the province.

activity-description.narrative: Mine clearance will be taking place in Samangan province.

description.narrative: In Balk we are operating in Charhar kint, in the mountainous areas of the province. Balk province is in the North of Afgahinstan sharing a border with Uzbekistan and Tajikistan with active cross-border trade. The capital Mazar - i - Sharif is a central Northern trade hub. Balk has an abundance of agricultural land and many farmers keep livestock, mostly cattle. Although security incidents do happen, Balkh is not an active conflict province.

activity-description.narrative: Teams are conducting mine clearance in Charhar kint, south of the city of Mazar, in the mountainous fields above the villages.

description.narrative: Baghlan province is located in the North of Afghanistan linking central and northern regions with the Hindu Kush mountain range, a central feature. The capital, Puli-Khumri sits 1,700 metres above sea level. Baghlan has insecure areas, particularly in Tala wa Barfak, but HALO's reputation and excellent community liaison mitigates against any risk to deminers.

activity-description.narrative: Teams are conducting mine clearance in five districts across Baghlan province

description.narrative: Khaki Jabbar of Kabul province is a primarily mountainous district 25km South East of the capital. Communities live at the bottom of the mountains and generally own livestock, using the land for grazing, pastures and collecting firewood. The working conditions can be remote and clearance tasks far from roads or villages.

activity-description.narrative: Three activities are being conducted in this area. Mine Clearance, MRE and Victim Assistance. Mine clearance is taking place on hills and mountains, whilst MRE, to compliment this is taking place in the adjacent mine-impacted communities. AOAD are also providing tailoring business and chickens to disabled individuals identified in the same villages.

sector.narrative: Manual and Mechanical Mine clearance: 18 manual teams of 6 Afghan staff and 1 mechanical team of 5 Afghan staff will conduct clearance of 71 Confirmed Hazardous Areas in 24 communities across 5 provinces. 441.49 ha of land will be released for grazing, foraging, agriculture and development.

Victim Assistance: Vocational training and assistance will be provided for victims by AOAD - a first time partnership. This will increase livelihoods opportunities and well-being. MRE: 1 mixed-gender CORE team will conduct 288 sessions for 2,880 men, women, boy and girls across mine-impacted communities increasing safe behaviour. Mixed-gender will encourage equal number of sessions for female attendees. 15250: EOD call outs The CORE team will conduct 120 EOD call-outs, responding to and destroying any ERW found by communities. Cancellation of land and Community Assessments: Survey teams will assess each minefield before clearance, and some areas are likely to be cancelled. The team will more accurately define the remaining mined areas as part of a community-led process.During the community survey process, and assessing the mine problem, a basic needs assessments will also be conducted.
WAD - Weapons & Ammunition Disposal 1 WAD team will conduct excavation and disposal of buried ammunition caches. 1 CORE Team will also dispose of ERW found in the course of survey/needs assessments.

description.narrative: Quarterly total paid to AOAD by HALO

comment.narrative: 5,879 people benefitted directly from EORE in 2020.

As we adjusted the target for the number of direct MRE beneficiaries, also the indicator target has been revised. Due to greater than expected amounts of ammunition being recovered, more MRE sessions were delivered

The over-achieving on this annual target is caused by more sessions of MRE being given than initially planned, while simultaneously having more recipients present per session than expected. Additional sessions were given to children especially to address the need on the ground. Boys and girls were prioritised as MRE recipients as they are most likely to handle unknown objects they come across and accidently detonate mines or other explosive remnants of war.

The over-achieving on this annual target is caused by more sessions of MRE being given than initially planned, while simultaneously having more recipients present per session than expected. It was predicted approximately 10 people would attend a session, but the average number of participants was 21. The targets have been revised for 2018.

title.narrative: Percentage of direct beneficiaries surveyed demonstrating increased safe behaviour towards the dangers of ERW/mines following RE activities

description.narrative: Surveys are conducted systematically before and after each MRE sessions. HALO MRE staff ask a series of questions to the beneficiaries to assess the knowledge of the participants. To ensure homogeniety of the data, the questions are binairies and require simple Yes/No answers.

comment.narrative: >99% of surveyed beneficiaries (1,430/1,431 respondents) demonstrated increased knowledge on safe behaviours by answering at least one question correctly after the session which they had answered incorrectly before.

The original target was based on percentage of direct beneficiaries showing increased knowledge from a baseline of 38 sampled MRE participants in provinces where NL mine clearance occurred. As such, the target was based on limited data. The revised 2018 target is based on a larger sample of 742 MRE participants. The new target should provide for a more accurate indicator.

The target is set based on percentage of direct beneficiaries showing increased safe behaviour from a baseline of 38 sampled MRE participants in provinces where NL mine clearance is taking place. As such, the target was based on limited data. The provided output total percentage is derived from 742 sampled MRE participants. The target will be updated for 2018 as more data has been accumulated.
2018: This indicator is derived from behavioural questions posed in the pre and post MRE survey. There are two key questions focusing on changed behaviour: What should you do if you see a UXO? And what should you do if you find yourself in a minefield? 82% demonstrated increased safe behaviour when answering the first question and 61% demonstrated increased safe behaviour when answering the second question. An average of these two percentages was used (72%) to indicate an improvement in safe behaviour. The initial target was based on a previous baseline that involved relatively few participants and therefore did not reflect the wider population. The target may be revised for the next project year.

title.narrative: Percentage of direct beneficiaries surveyed reporting improved livelihoods (%)

description.narrative: Surveys are conducted systematically before and after each MRE sessions. HALO MRE staff ask a series of questions to the beneficiaries to assess the knowledge of the participants. To ensure homogeniety of the data, the questions are binairies and require simple Yes/No answers.

comment.narrative: 100% of beneficiaries surveyed in 2018 in areas where mine clearance is complete say that their livelihoods have improved. This is due to the fact that even increased ability to collect firewood for household use or sell on the market improves the livelihood of a household. It removes the requirement to buy firewood on the market and allows beneficiaries to sell it.
100% of surveyed beneficiaries (30/30 respondents) said their livelihoods had improved since clearance in their communities.

This target will currently remain the same, However, we are planning to conduct a post demining survey, which may provide a better indication of improved livelihoods than the baseline information the target is based on. If this is the case, we will request to revise the target.

title.narrative: Percentage of direct beneficiaries surveyed reporting improved access to services and infrastructure (%)

description.narrative: Surveys are conducted systematically before and after each MRE sessions. HALO MRE staff ask a series of questions to the beneficiaries to assess the knowledge of the participants. To ensure homogeniety of the data, the questions are binairies and require simple Yes/No answers.

comment.narrative: 100% of beneficiaries surveyed in 2018 in areas where mine clearance is complete say that their access to services and infrastructure improved. This is due to the fact that most of the beneficiaries surveyed in 2018 live next to roads that used to be mined. After clearance, most beneficiaries were able to benefit from cleared roads and other beneficiaries had increased access to other services and infrastructure. The initial target was based on the number of beneficiaries that reported blocked access to services and infrastructure during the baseline. However, changes in the workplan occurred and different communities were included in the livelihoods survey. Likewise, even though direct access might not have been block by mines, they might have easier and shorter travelling distance to other areas.
100% of beneficiaries surveyed in 2019 in areas where mine clearance is complete say that their access to services and infrastructure improved.

100% of surveyed beneficiaries (30/30 respondents) said that clearance in their communities had improved their access to essential services and infrastructure in some way (including schools, healthcare, markets, water sources, roads, and play areas for children).

This target will currently remain the same, However, we are planning to conduct a post demining survey, which may provide a better indication of improved access than the baseline information the target is based on. If this is the case, we will request to revise the target.

comment.narrative: During April and May, MRE activities were suspended in Afghanistan, by order of the national authority, as a safety measure against the COVID-19 pandemic. Activities resumed in June, using indirect methods of delivery (including megaphone broadcasts and posters), in combination with safety messaging on COVID-19 prevention measures. Teams received training from a WHO-led initiative on how to provide this messaging. The number of beneficiaries reached through MRE going forward will be reduced due to these measures.

Teams did not reach as many girls as expected, due to the suspension of EORE for most of quarter two and the reduced session sizes thereafter. Due to the overachievements in previous years this did not have a high impact on the overall project achievements.

comment.narrative: As was the trend in previous quarters, the number of indirect beneficiaries significantly overachieved the overall project target. The reason is that the data of minefields and beneficiaries were collected several years prior to the actual mine clearance activities. The overall project target was thus based on outdated data. During the time gap between survey and clearance, the number of beneficiaries have increased (due to general population growth, IDPs, etc..). To better account for the number of indirect beneficiaries, the target for 2018 will be revised.

Conflict induced as well as general population movements on the ground result in discrepancies between the data the targets are based on and the current situation.

The number of beneficiaries is less this quarter because many of the tasks are in communities where NL funded clearance teams worked last year. To avoid double counting of beneficiaries, they were no counted for this quarter. More beneficiaries will be reached in future tasks.

The teams worked in new areas which resulted in an increase in beneficiaries. Beneficiary targets are based on the numbers recorded in the IMSMA database. These numbers are often several years old, resulting in recent population movements and growth not being taken into consideration. comment.narrative: (unchanged)
A new VA partner, Development and Ability Organisation (DAO), has been selected as HALO's VA partner. A contract is currently being finalised and activities are due to commence in September 2019
DAO activities concluded in the previous quarter

DAO conducted VA activities from September 2019 to February 2020, reaching people in need of physiotherapy assistance in the East and South of Afghanistan. Due to the high level of need, DAO staff increased the level of support, leading to an overachievement of the planned targets.

DAO conducted VA activities from September 2019 to February 2020, reaching people in need of physiotherapy assistance in the East and South of Afghanistan. Due to the high level of need, DAO staff increased the level of support, leading to an overachievement of the planned targets.

DAO reached more beneficiaries than the planned target for the first quarter, as the need for victim assistance was so great, and communities were requesting as much support as possible. These figures only include January and February.
New VA partners have been approached to carry out these activities.

VA partner, DAO is providing life-saving and life-changing services to ERW victims. Multiple services are often provided to a single victim. In this quarter HALO identified a double counting of some beneficiaries as some people receive multiple services. Physical and emotional needs often require a multi-disciplinary approach that DAO can provide to accident victims. This double counting has been retrospectively corrected in previous quarters for both outputs and targets. Future targets have revised downward slightly to reflect the expected unique beneficiaries. The overall reduction in target beneficiaries is 7% for the entire project. DAO will still be working at the same capacity. This change has no budgetary implications.

description.narrative: The area in square metres cleared through the removal and/or destruction of all specified mine and ERW hazards to a pre-determined depth, using manual or mechanical assets.

comment.narrative: As in previous quarters, the number of MRE recipients surpassed the target by a significant percentage. The over-achievement is caused by the MRE target being set too modestly. The target is based on 10 recipients attending a session. The results reveal that each session was attended by an average of 21 participants. To account for the higher number of attendees, the target for 2018 was revised to 4,800 beneficiaries. The new target is based on each session being attended by approximately 20 recipients.

As in previous quarters, the number of MRE recipients surpassed the target by a significant percentage. The over-achievement is caused by the MRE target being set too modestly. The target is based on 10 recipients attending a session. The results reveal that each session was attended by an average of 21 participants. To account for the higher number of attendees, the target for 2018 was revised to 4,800 beneficiaries. The new target is based on each session being attended by approximately 20 recipients.

As the CORE team prioritised survey and re-survey activities, less MRE sessions were conducted in the first quarter. The teams will focus conducting more MRE in upcoming quarters. As fewer sessions were conducted, fewer beneficiaries were reached this quarter. The majority of MRE sessions were conducted at schools.

Boys and girls were prioritised as MRE recipients as they are most likely to handle unknown objects they come across and accidently detonate mines or other explosive remnants of war. In addition, as MRE sessions are delivered at times when men and women are often at work or busy with household tasks, the team could not easily reach adults for MRE resulting in an underachievement. Instead, attendees are encouraged to share their newly acquired knowledge with family members and friends.

Boys and girls were prioritised as MRE recipients as they are most likely to handle unknown objects they come across and accidently detonate mines or other explosive remnants of war. In addition, as MRE sessions are delivered at times when men and women are often at work or busy with household tasks, the team could not easily reach adults for MRE resulting in an underachievement. Instead, attendees are encouraged to share their newly acquired knowledge with family members and friends.

During April and May, MRE activities were suspended in Afghanistan, by order of the national authority, as a safety measure against the COVID-19 pandemic. Activities resumed in June, using indirect methods of delivery (including megaphone broadcasts and posters), in combination with safety messaging on COVID-19 prevention measures. Teams received training from a WHO-led initiative on how to provide this messaging. The number of beneficiaries reached through MRE going forward will be reduced due to these measures.

In 2020, EORE outputs during the second quarter were affected by the national response to the COVID-19 pandemic. Starting in April, DMAC issued a stop order on all risk education activities, and EORE teams suspended their work. Between April and June, HALO worked with DMAC, the WHO, and other mine action partners to create a revised procedure for conducting EORE safely. This included social distancing and hygiene measures, reduced group sizes, and the use of indirect methods such as posters. Teams were able to resume sessions in June, and although these reached fewer beneficiaries, they had the added benefit of including safety messaging on COVID-19. The number of men reached exceeded the planned anual target, despite the two-month suspension.

In 2020, EORE outputs during the second quarter were affected by the national response to the COVID-19 pandemic. Starting in April, DMAC issued a stop order on all risk education activities, and EORE teams suspended their work. Between April and June, HALO worked with DMAC, the WHO, and other mine action partners to create a revised procedure for conducting EORE safely. This included social distancing and hygiene measures, reduced group sizes, and the use of indirect methods such as posters. Teams were able to resume sessions in June, and although these reached fewer beneficiaries, they had the added benefit of including safety messaging on COVID-19. The number of men reached exceeded the planned anual target, despite the two-month suspension.

No MRE beneficiaries were reached during Q4 as the CORE team did not carry out any MRE activities (Contract target for MRE recipients had already been surpassed) and instead focused on survey and resurvey of minefield perimeters.
The CORE team conducted extensive survey and re-survey work. In subsequent quarters, CORE teams will prioritise MRE in order to achieve the annual target

The CORE team provided more MRE sessions than anticipated. As a result of a large amount of ammunition being uncovered in Paghman district of Kabul province and accidents involving children occurring in this district, the CORE team carried out extra MRE sessions for the communities in this area. The mixed gender CORE team also provided several sessions at schools in these communities to ensure no children were excluded and that they are well informed of the dangers of mines/ERW.

Total contract target was surpassed in 2017. The target of MRE beneficiaries expected sessions to be attended by equal amounts of men, women, boys and girls. However, the majority of sessions were held at schools and attended by children. It was expected that at least 4,800 people in total would participate in MRE sessions, this total number was surpassed.

However, the majority of sessions were held at schools and attended by children. It was expected that at least 4,800 people in total would participate in MRE sessions, this total number was surpassed.

comment.narrative: As was the trend in previous quarters, the number of indirect beneficiaries significantly overachieved the overall project target. The reason is that the data of minefields and beneficiaries were collected several years prior to the actual mine clearance activities. The overall project target was thus based on outdated data. During the time gap between survey and clearance, the number of beneficiaries have increased (due to general population growth, IDPs, etc..). To better account for the number of indirect beneficiaries, the target for 2018 will be revised.

In Q4, no MRE sessions were conducted as the contract target had already been surpassed. The CORE team instead prioritized conducting survey of new tasks and re-survey of existing tasks.

The CORE team conducted less MRE sessions this quarter as there were less team months deployed. The team was funded by the Netherlands for May 2018. However, in April and June, the team was funded by another donor.

The CORE team provided more MRE sessions than anticipated. As a result of a large amount of ammunition being uncovered in Paghman district of Kabul province and accidents involving children occurring in this district, the CORE team carried out extra MRE sessions for the communities in this area. The mixed gender CORE team also provided several sessions at schools in these communities to ensure no children were excluded and that they are well informed of the dangers of mines/ERW.

The CORE team provided more MRE sessions than anticipated. As a result of high numbers of IDPs and returnees, the CORE team responded to an increased humanitarian need for the lifesaving information by delivering additional MRE sessions. The mixed gender CORE team also provided several sessions at schools to ensure no children were excluded.

The number of MRE sessions significantly surpassed the target, because the target was based on one mixed gender CORE team providing MRE to at risk communities. However, in Q4 and Q5, there were two mixed gender CORE teams providing MRE, thus enhancing the number of sessions. The target was also set too modestly. Thus the 2018 target has been revised to 240 sessions.

The annual target for males benefitting from victim assistance was under-achieved, while the annual target for females benefitting from assistance was over-achieved. The reason for this is that the population of female victims was higher than that of males in the selected communities. In total, 47 victims were assisted, which is slightly higher than the target of 45 victims assisted. In upcoming project years, the balance between male and female victims is expected to balance out.

VA partner, DAO is providing life-saving and life-changing services to ERW victims. Multiple services are often provided to a single victim. In this quarter HALO identified a double counting of some beneficiaries as some people receive multiple services. Physical and emotional needs often require a multi-disciplinary approach that DAO can provide to accident victims. This double counting has been retrospectively corrected in previous quarters for both outputs and targets. Future targets have revised downward slightly to reflect the expected unique beneficiaries. The overall reduction in target beneficiaries is 7% for the entire project. DAO will still be working at the same capacity. This change has no budgetary implications.

comment.narrative: HALO clearance teams cleared 1,240,133 m2 in 2019. This is 141,533 m2 over the target for HALO Afghanistan in 2019. Teams were able to clear at a faster than expected rate because of low metal contamination in tasks, especially those located in the Ruyi du Ab district of Samangan province. HALO Afghanistan has been able to take advantage of these favourable ground conditions and add more large area tasks to the work plan to overachieve on clearance targets.

HALO clearance teams cleared 1,240,133 m2 in 2019. This is 141,533 m2 over the target for HALO Afghanistan in 2019. Teams were able to clear at a faster than expected rate because of low metal contamination in tasks, especially those located in the Ruyi du Ab district of Samangan province. HALO Afghanistan has been able to take advantage of these favourable ground conditions and add more large area tasks to the work plan to overachieve on clearance targets.

In 2020, manual and mechanical clearance led to the release of 659,278 square metres of contaminated land. This was 89% of the overall target for the year; combined with the outputs of battle area clearance, teams met 175% of this target (see below).

comment.narrative: As in previous quarters, the number of MRE recipients surpassed the target by a significant percentage. The over-achievement is caused by the MRE target being set too modestly. The target is based on 10 recipients attending a session. The results reveal that each session was attended by an average of 21 participants. To account for the higher number of attendees, the target for 2018 was revised to 4,800 beneficiaries. The new target is based on each session being attended by approximately 20 recipients.

As in previous quarters, the number of MRE recipients surpassed the target by a significant percentage. The over-achievement is caused by the MRE target being set too modestly. The target is based on 10 recipients attending a session. The results reveal that each session was attended by an average of 21 participants. To account for the higher number of attendees, the target for 2018 was revised to 4,800 beneficiaries. The new target is based on each session being attended by approximately 20 recipients.

Boys and girls were prioritised as MRE recipients as they are most likely to handle unknown objects they come across and accidently detonate mines or other explosive remnants of war. In addition, as MRE sessions are delivered at times when men and women are often at work or busy with household tasks, the team could not easily reach adults for MRE resulting in a slight underachievement. Instead, attendees are encouraged to share their newly acquired knowledge with family members and friends.

Boys and girls were prioritised as MRE recipients as they are most likely to handle unknown objects they come across and accidently detonate mines or other explosive remnants of war. In addition, as MRE sessions are delivered at times when men and women are often at work or busy with household tasks, the team could not easily reach adults for MRE resulting in a slight underachievement. Instead, attendees are encouraged to share their newly acquired knowledge with family members and friends.

During April and May, MRE activities were suspended in Afghanistan, by order of the national authority, as a safety measure against the COVID-19 pandemic. Activities resumed in June, using indirect methods of delivery (including megaphone broadcasts and posters), in combination with safety messaging on COVID-19 prevention measures. Teams received training from a WHO-led initiative on how to provide this messaging. The number of beneficiaries reached through MRE going forward will be reduced due to these measures.

In 2020, EORE outputs during the second quarter were affected by the national response to the COVID-19 pandemic. Starting in April, DMAC issued a stop order on all risk education activities, and EORE teams suspended their work. Between April and June, HALO worked with DMAC, the WHO, and other mine action partners to create a revised procedure for conducting EORE safely. This included social distancing and hygiene measures, reduced group sizes, and the use of indirect methods such as posters. Teams were able to resume sessions in June, and although these reached fewer beneficiaries, they had the added benefit of including safety messaging on COVID-19. The number of women reached exceeded the planned anual target, despite the two-month suspension.

In 2020, EORE outputs during the second quarter were affected by the national response to the COVID-19 pandemic. Starting in April, DMAC issued a stop order on all risk education activities, and EORE teams suspended their work. Between April and June, HALO worked with DMAC, the WHO, and other mine action partners to create a revised procedure for conducting EORE safely. This included social distancing and hygiene measures, reduced group sizes, and the use of indirect methods such as posters. Teams were able to resume sessions in June, and although these reached fewer beneficiaries, they had the added benefit of including safety messaging on COVID-19. The number of women reached exceeded the planned anual target, despite the two-month suspension.
In the communities where the CORE team was working, women were unavailable to attend the MRE sessions. Instead, the team focused on MRE for children at schools.

No MRE beneficiaries were reached during Q4 as the CORE team did not carry out any MRE activities (Contract target for MRE recipients had already been surpassed) and instead focused on survey and resurvey of minefield perimeters.
The CORE team conducted extensive survey and re-survey work. In subsequent quarters, CORE teams will prioritise MRE in order to achieve the annual target

The CORE team provided more MRE sessions than anticipated. As a result of a large amount of ammunition being uncovered in Paghman district of Kabul province and accidents involving children occurring in this district, the CORE team carried out extra MRE sessions for the communities in this area. The mixed gender CORE team also provided several sessions at schools in these communities to ensure no children were excluded and that they are well informed of the dangers of mines/ERW.

Total contract target was surpassed in 2017. The target of MRE beneficiaries expected sessions to be attended by equal amounts of men, women, boys and girls. However, the majority of sessions were held at schools and attended by children. It was expected that at least 4,800 people in total would participate in MRE sessions, this total number was surpassed.

As the tasks in Laghman were smaller, the number of tasks was increased to ensure the annual target of clearance would be achieved.

Five tasks were completed during the reporting period. An additional six tasks started during the reporting period and remain ongoing. This quarter, changes to the workplan were made to accommodate the visit of the Dutch Foreign Minister. The number of tasks was revised to from 19 to 21. The tasks are larger than those on the previous workplan, resulting in approximately the same amount of land being cleared. As such, no adjustments to the clearance target are necessary.
